title: Divorce what if prior to marrying both single & only 1 pd all closing cost, furniture etc. is not part of Comm property?
question: I am in divorce without an attorney & plain don't have the money to hire one and can't get one tried everything, my wife is trying to force sale of our house & wants 1/2 of everything. However, that only applies to whatever we obtained during the marriage correct? As we bought house & the mortgage was in both our names as being single prior to marrying each other & "prior to getting married while single only one of us paid for everything, all down payment, closing cost etc on house, as well to upgrade the house, as well purchased all furniture in the home & have documents to prove". So even though we married after everything above was purchased by only one of us, & while both being single, "is the one that paid for everything while single entitled to that amount to be repaid out of any profit from sale of house prior to 50% split of any profit on sale of home.? Please answer in detail and Please I have tried & impossible to get attorney so Please don't say get attorney as impossible tried every way legal aid etc and can't get one. Please answer in detail.
question_tags: Divorce,Contested divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Family law,Fees
answers: I doubt you have tried '"everything" as I feel fairly sure you have not tried limited scope representation. Google it. Also "unbundled services".

You are entitled to a reimbursement for any separate property contributions to the community. Anything that you purchased or contributed before the marriage is yours. So basically, when you sell the house, you'll get your money back first then split whatever is remaining (equity & debt).

You are entitled to reimbursement for your separate property contributions provided that you can prove them. You are only entitled to reimbursement for upgrades to the extent that those upgrades enhanced the home's value. It will not be a 50-50 split, - you should get more - but you have the burden to show why.
Attorney fees could be tied to any cash distributions of the estate division. That might help.
